TitleMain.Title: Evaluation of health and social situation in the Republic of Chad : report of the WHO mission 9-15 November 1982.

Author.CollectiveName: World Health Organization. Regional Office for Africa.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Brazzaville, Congo, World Health Organization, Regional Office for Africa, 1982.
PublicationInfo.Place: Brazzaville, Congo, World Health Organization, Regional Office for Africa,

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The World Health Organization (WHO) sent a mission to Chad on 9-15 November 1982 to 1) identify the essential features of the health and social situation in Chad, 2) determine the immediate and short-term health and social needs of Chad, and 3) identify priority programs for rapid improvement of the health and social situation. The mission noted the disorganization of the national health system and the precarious health conditions of the Chadian population. This situation is the result of the civil war which has ravaged the country since 1979. Chad's formerly sufficiently well-organized health system is at present greatly underutilized due to 1) a deterioration of the existing infrastructure, 2) a shortage of qualified national or foreign personnel, 3) a marked shortage everywhere of materials, equipment, drugs, and vaccines, and 4) the mobility of the local population due to drought and political events. The health and social services are still operating moderately because of the commitments of several Chadian health and social workers and support from international and nongovernmental agencies and religious missions. Water supply and sanitation conditions are alarming. Foreign financial, material, technical, and human support is essential to revive Chadian health and social services. The most urgent actions are to 1) supply the country with essential drugs, 2) revive the expanded program on immunization in densely populated areas, 3) repair premises and equipment in health and social units, 4) strengthen the work of social centers, especially for nutrition and maternal-child health , 5) identify funds to pay for foreign health teams, 6) implement primary health care as soon as possible, 7) award a reasonable number of fellowships for overseas training of the qualified staff Chad needs, 8) make water points serviceable, especially in towns, 9) strengthen public health information and education, 10) strengthen the national health information system, and 11) make the best use of the services of specialized UN agencies and WHO intercountry projects.

Among the individuals, institutions, and legislative acts mentioned are Edward L. Griffin, the Dept. of Agriculture, the Food and Drug Administration, and the Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act of 1938.

Mr. Cromartie was an inspector with the Department of Agriculture and assigned to the Food and Drug Administration in 1931. From 1945 until his retirement, in 1966, he was an administrator of enforcement and inspection with the Insecticide Division of the Dept. of Agriculture.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Richard Lamm provides the legal viewpoint of the discussion, starting with the passing of a more liberal abortion law in Colorado in 1967. Dr. Guttmacher, an obstetrician and gynecologist, represents the view that abortion laws should be liberalized, to provide accessibility not now available to the poor, and that the indications should be broadened from mental health or danger of life. Dr. Ayd, a psychiatrist, represents the view that the fetus is a living being, and is concerned that the psychological aftermath of an abortion can be as serious as the mental state induced by an unwanted pregnancy.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Last inspected: 198101. Condition complete; good.
Country of Producing Entity: United States
Panel, Alan F. Guttmacher, Frank Ayd Jr. ; moderator, Richard D. Lamm.

TitleMain.Title: The epidemiology of pesticide poisonings
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [motion picture] / Consumer Protection and Environmental Health Services, Office of Product Safety ; produced by National Medical Audiovisual Center.

Author.CollectiveName: Consumer Protection and Environmental Health Service. Office of Product Safety.
National Medical Audiovisual Center.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: [Washington] : The Office ; [Atlanta : for loan by National Medical Audiovisual Center], 1969.
PublicationInfo.Publisher: The Office ; [Atlanta : for loan by National Medical Audiovisual Center],

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Answer print : 1 film reel of 1 (720 ft.) : sd., col, ; 16 mm.
Duplication copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (Betacam SP) (19 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videodisc of 1 (DVD) (19 min.) : sd., col. ; 4 3/4 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: The purpose of this presentation is to describe and demonstrate the epidemiological aspects of pesticide poisonings. This objective is achieved with the use of chest x-rays and clinical patients. The terminology is first defined and statistics cited to establish the prevalence of pesticide poisonings. The program stresses the importance of the team approach in the investigative process. The purposes of an epidemiological study are noted to be definition of the causes and sources of the epidemic, aid in handling large outbreaks and prevention of epidemics by public education and encouragement of appropriate legislation by local, state, and federal governments. The disciplines which should be represented on the epidemiological team include medicine, public health, chemistry, and biostatistics. According to this presentation the three steps to be followed in an investigation are data collection, formulation of the hypothesis and testing the hypothesis. Two cases are then presented to demonstrate the application of these principles.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Rating: Recommended.
Review date: June 1975.
Reviewer: Association of American Medical Colleges (AAMC).
Learning method: Support.

TitleMain.Title: Medical defense against biological warfare : basic considerations, Part 1

Author.CollectiveName: Fordel Films.
United States. Navy Dept.

PublicationInfo.Imprint: Washington, DC : Dept. of the Navy, 1959.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Answer print : 1 film reel of 1 (684 ft.) : sd., col. ; 16 mm.
Viewing copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (19 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This film outlines the basic considerations which must underlie a medical defense against biological weapons. The military purposes for the use of biological warfare are: the disruption of industrial areas without destruction of facilities; the disruption and halting of training after attacks on military training camps; the temporary neutralization of isolated military bases; to seek out personnel in places inaccessable to "hard" weapons; as an adjunct to scorched earth tactics; to disable large numbers of personnel secretly; and to attack crops and animals to reduce food supply. The criteria for selecting a biological warfare agent are: infectivity, pathogenicity, persistency, casualty effectiveness, possibilityof artificial transmission, immunization and therapy, and availability. The technology necessary for the production of biological warfare agents is already known. The right organism or group of organisms would then be chosen to produce thedesired effect. Methods of disseminating biological warfare agents have been classified as small-scale miscellaneous or large-scale airborne. Small-scale methods could be used by saboteurs. Several examples of this are shown. Airborne methods could use rockets, guided missiles, and long-range artillery. Other methods shown are infiltrators from the sea and biological warheads launched from ships. The most likely method of airborne large-scale delivery of biological warfareagents would be by aircraft. These planes could be carrier- or land-based and are shown dropping specially constructed bomblets to achieve maximum coverage. Airplanes using storage tanks and atomizers could be used (also shown). A well-planned medical defense against biological warfare is necessary. Shots include: military installations; troops in garrison and in the field; laboratory, clinic, and ward scenes; animation is used to illustrate how agents can be disseminated; facilities for producing pathogens on a large scale.

TitleMain.Title: Medical defense against biological warfare : basic preparation before attack, Part 2

Author.CollectiveName: Fordel Films.
United States. Navy Dept.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Answer print : 1 film reel of 1 (649 ft.) : sd., col. ; 16 mm.
Color reversal intermediate : 1 film reel of 1 (649 ft.) : sd., col. ; 16 mm.
Duplication copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (Betacam SP) (19 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (18 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This film presents an overview of naval planning in preparation for a biological warfare attack. In a covert attack, physical protective measures probably would not be applied in time to prevent an outbreak of disease. Therefore, medical counter-measures would become the first line of defense. In an overt attack, physical measures would become the first line of defense, with medical measures a very important second line of defense. The medical department bears the responsibility of reducing the number of casualties, to minimize the degree and duration of incapacitation, and to reduce the mortality rate. Air is expected to be the principal vehicle of transmission of biological warfare agents. The medical department is responsible for gathering samples of the pathogens used in the attack, identifying the pathogens, and determining their antibiotic sensitivity. Successful defense against biological attack necessitates coordinated planning within and among administrative districts. Naval officers are shown discussing a possible attack using biological agents transmitted by air and by water. The basic plans for defense at a naval base are presented. The sanitation officers are alertedto their duties. Sanitation personnel begin testing chlorine levels in the base's water supply. They also increase the chemical control of any insect vectors that may be present, outdoors and indoors, in larval or adult forms. Physical countermeasures such as repairing window screens are carried out. The levels of vector presence are monitored. Health hazards teams receive stepped-up training in air, surface, and disarmed munitions sampling. Clinical samples are taken at sick call for laboratory analysis. The medical officer begins modifications in the medical laboratory and trains laboratory personnel for the new circumstances, especially in regard to speed and volume of work. Plans are also made to provide additional hospital beds and other medical facilities and supplies. Drug supplies for the treatment of diseases the attack may engender are kept in readiness. Mass immunization of personnel is carried out. All personnel are well-indoctrinated in biological warfare defense. Shots include: worker in biological warfare protective gear; drug supply storeroom.

TitleMain.Title: Medical defense against biological warfare : basic plan after an attack, Part 3
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [motion picture] Department of the Navy, United States of America ; Fordel Films, Inc.

Author.CollectiveName: United States. Navy.
Fordel Films.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Answer print : 1 film reel of 1 (598 ft.) : sd., col. ; 16 mm.
Viewing copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (17 min.) : sd., col. ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: In this film, the medical countermeasures instituted in defense of a hypothetical biological warfare attack on a small group of islands is demonstrated. Immediately after the attack, the medical department is faced with four urgent tasks. They are: first aid, emergency treatment, and decontamination of casualties; identification of the biological warfare agent; medical care for the exposed and infected personnel; and control of the environment and of the personnel. First echelon medical service consists of teams that search for casualties and give first aid in attack areas, litter bearer teams, field aid station teams to provide emergency treatment and prepare casualties for evacuation, and ambulance teams that evacuate casualties to rear echelons. All of the above are shown carrying out typical duties. The ABC health hazards team takes samples of the biological agent. Workers are shown doing this in full protective gear. Samples are taken to to the first-level detection and identification laboratory where work on the samples begins at once. Some samples are also sent to second-level military laboratories for analysis. If the samples cannot be identified in the second-level laboratory, they may be sent to a third level military or civilian laboratory. If immunizations are available, they are given as soon as the pathogen is identified. If they are not available, the incubation period may be prolonged by the use of drugs and antibiotics. Early specific therapy is given to personnel in whom the agent has been identified. Environments and food and water supplies are checked. A search is conducted for vectors. If an epidemic begins, isolation wards should be used for infected patients. Early case finding is important in stopping an epidemic. Quarantine or evacuations of the primary area of contamination may be necessary.

TitleMain.Title: What you should know about biological warfare
TitleMain.OtherInformation: [videorecording] / a WAAM production for the Dumont Network.

Author.CollectiveName: WAAM (Television station : Baltimore, Md.)
Dumont Television Network.
Johns Hopkins University.

PhysicalDescription.Extent: Master : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (29 min.) : sd., b&w ; 1/2 in.
Viewing copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (VHS) (29 min.) : sd., b&w ; 1/2 in.
Duplication copy : 1 videocassette of 1 (Betacam SP) (30 min.) : sd., b&w ; 1/2 in.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: This video, originally produced for television, discusses the myths about biological warfare and the dangers of spreading misinformation. The production provides a definition of biological warfare and its effects on people, and uses demonstrations and still photographs. Dr. Victor Haas of the United States Public Health Service and the National Institutes of Health discusses influenza, Q fever, and encephalitis as possible instruments of biological warfare. Dr. Alexander Langnore from the Communicable Disease Center in Atlanta comments on possible contamination of air and water, and on the defenses put in place by the Dept. of Agriculture, the United States Public Health Service, and the Bureau of Customs. Dr. Norvi C. Kieffer, director of the Health and Special Weapons Division of the Federal Defense Administration, discusses procedures implemented on the national level.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Title on cassette label: Truth about biological warfare.

TitleMain.Title: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Office of the Director, Martin M. Cummings papers

Author.CollectiveName: National Library of Medicine (U.S.). Office of the Director.

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Scope and Contents: Administrative records, correspondence, medical research files, publications, and speeches document the administrative and medical career of Martin Marc Cummings, Director of the National Library of Medicine between 1964-1984. Materials cover Cummings' career as National Library of Medicine Director, Director Emeritus starting in 1984, and his portions of research career on sarcoidosis and tuberculosis from 1948 to 1963. The bulk of the collection consists of Cummings' administrative files as Director of the National Library of Medicine. Of special interest is Series II: NLM Administration, 1956-1982, documenting Cummings major institutional and political accomplishments such as the development of the NLM Extramural Program, the Lister Hill National Center for Biomedical Communication, and MEDLARS. In addition, Series VI: Speeches, 1961-1983 and Series X: Publications, 1946-1982 document NLM's major milestones and achievements during his leadership. His inter-governmental work in the area of science policy, education, and computer science is best reflected in Series V: Committees and Series IV: Subject Files.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Organized into 11 series: I. Series I: Personal and Biographical; Series II: NLM Director Correspondence; Series III: NLM Administration; Series IV: Subject Files; Series V: Committees; Series VI: Speeches; Series VII: Travel; Series VIII: NLM Director Emeritus; Series IX: Sarcoidosis and Tuberculosis Research; Series X: Publications; Series XI: Professional Associations.
Portions of the collection are restricted.

Preferred citation: National Library of Medicine (U.S.) Office of the Director. Office of the Director, Martin M. Cummings Papers. 1944-1989. Located in: Modern Manuscripts Collection, History of Medicine Division, National Library of Medicine, Bethesda, MD; MS C 554
Copyright is in the public domain.
Transfer, NLM/OD, 1989 and 2001, Accession 564, 573, 580, 2001-16.

Biographical Sketch: Martin Marc Cummings (1920- ) medical educator, physician, scientific administrator, and medical librarian, made significant contributions to medical informatics and librarianship. As Director of the National Library of Medicine from 1964 to 1984, he guided the Library into the age of technology while broadening its mission. n 1949 Cummings joined the U.S. Veterans Administration's Department of Medicine and Surgery. He served from 1949 to 1953 as Chief of the Tuberculosis Section and Director of the Tuberculosis Research Laboratory at the V.A.'s Lawson General in Chamblee, Georgia. In 1953 he became Director of Research Services at the V.A.'s Central Office in Washington, D.C., serving until 1959. n 1961 Cummings accepted the position of Chief of the Office of International Research at the National Institutes of Health serving until 1963. Over the next year he served as Associate Director for Research Grants before becoming the Director of the National Library of Medicine in 1964. As Director of the National Library of Medicine Cummings embraced technology to improve the services offered by the Library. He oversaw the improvement of MEDLARS and developed new programs such as the Extramural Programs, Regional Library Network, Specialized Information Services, and the Toxicology Program. In addition, Cummings focused on gaining authority and funds for a Research and Development program which culminated on May 22, 1980 with the dedication of the Lister Hill National Center for Biomedical Communications. Other successes include his involvement with the passage of the Medical Library Assistance Act of October 22, 1965 authorizing the Library to aid the nation's medical libraries in expanding their services to the health community.
Finding aid available in Library and electronically: folder level control.

TitleMain.Title: Williams & Wilkins Co. v. The United States records,

Author.CollectiveName: Williams & Wilkins.
National Library of Medicine (U.S.)

OtherAbstract.AbstractText: Included are files from Martin Cummings and Scott Adams (Director and Deputy Director of the National Library of Medicine) and Albert Berkowitz (Reference Services division section chief) as well as subject and correspondence files.

NLMCatalogRecord.GeneralNote: Organized into 9 series: I. Copyright subject files; II. Incoming correspondence; III. Outgoing correspondence; IV. Inter-Office memoranda and notes; V. Legal documents; VI. Related copyright activities; VII. Copyright legislation; VIII. Williams & Wilkins Case publicity; IX. General articles on copyright.
Transfer by Ralph C. Williams, Sr. from the files of Chief Reference Services Div., NLM; 06/02/86; 424.

Legal suit brought by Williams & Wilkins Co. against the National Library of Medicine and the National Institute of Health on Feb. 27, 1968. The suit charged that the libraries had violated the company's copyright by duplicating articles for interlibrary loan from journals published by Williams & Wilkins. The case was settled by a split decision of the Supreme Court upholding the appeals court verdict that found for the government.
Finding guide available in the Library and electronically.
